awd_titl_txt: Transition Metal-Catalyzed Novel Cycloadditions for Organic Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Weiping Tang of the University of Wisconsin-Madison to develop novel transition metal-catalyzed cycloaddition reactions focused on generating valuable seven-membered rings. These new reactions have the potential to fill a significant knowledge gap in organic chemistry and lead to a fundamentally new body of research. Professor Tang is integrating his research into education plans through activities that increase the participation of underrepresented undergraduate and high school students. The broader impact of this work includes improved fundamental understanding on metal catalysis and cycloadditions, new chemical methods for the preparation of medicine and materials, and the training of students for careers in science. 

The project focuses on the development of rhodium-catalyzed [5+2]-cycloadditions of 3-acyloxy-1,4-enynes with alkynes, alkenes, allenes, and other pi-systems. Highly functionalized seven-membered rings are prepared from these readily available enynes. For example, various tropone-containing compounds can be efficiently synthesized using an alkyne as the 2-carbon component. With an alkene or allene as the 2-carbon component, multiple stereogenic centers are set within the seven-membered rings. Professor Tang is also investigating the mechanism and reactive intermediates involved in these novel [5+2]-cycloadditions. These new cycloaddition methods provide solutions for the longstanding challenge to develop efficient and stereoselective synthetic entries into mono- or polycyclic seven-membered rings.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

During the funding period of this NSF grant, we developed new types of Rh-catalyzed intramolecular [5+2] cycloadditions of 3-acyloxy-1,4-enynes with alkenes, alkynes, and allenes. Various skeletons were prepared stereoselectively. The chirality in the starting materials could often be transferred to the bicyclic products with high efficiency. In some cases, up to three new stereogenic centers could be generated diastereo- and enantioselectively. The resulting diene or triene moieties in the products could be converted to various functionalized seven-membered rings. We studied the mechanism of these reactions by collaborating with computational chemists. We also developed other types of cycloadditions using 1,4-enynes as the 5-carbon building blocks. We found that 3-hydroxy-1,4-enynes could serve as five-carbon synthons for Rh-catalyzed [5+1] cycloadditions, which allowed us to prepare highly substituted carbazoles and carbazole-containing heterocycles including tri-, tetra-, and pentacyclic heterocycles. We also found that the alkene part of 3-acyloxy-1,4-enynes could be embedded in an aromatic system such as aryl propargylic esters for facile [5+1] cycloadditions with carbon monoxide. Additionally, we demonstrated that the [5+1] cycloadditions of aryl propargylic esters with carbon monoxide could be applied to the synthesis of several benzofuran-containing natural products. Finally, we discovered a novel thermal hetero-[5+2] cycloaddition of oxidopyrylium with imines. Various complex polycyclic nitrogen-containing heterocycles were synthesized for the first time.

Broader Impacts:

During the funding period of this NSF grant, eight graduate students, one postdoctoral fellow, and eight undergraduate students were partially supported. The NSF funded projects improved or introduced necessary research skills to the postdoctoral fellow, graduate and undergraduate students. We also recruited four high school students to our lab through the Pre-College Enrichment Opportunity Program for Learning Excellence (PEOPLE) at UW-Madison during the summers of 2016, 2017, and 2018. All high school students were under-represented minorities (URMs). The experiences gave the high school students their first exposure to the research aspect of science and technology, and these experiences may inspire them to pursue a scientific career in the future.

Eight publications were produced through this NSF grant. Research products including procedures of new methods and characterization data of new compounds were published in journals that are widely read by scientists in the field. These journals are included in databases that mine the published literature, such as SciFinder, Web of Science, PubChem, and PubMed.

In summary, new 5-carbon building blocks were also developed for [5+n] cycloadditions. These reactions can lead to new methods for the preparation of six and seven-membered rings and new knowledge about cycloadditions and metal carbene chemistry. The new reaction we developed may find utilities in manufacturing chemicals and pharmaceuticals, which will improve environmental conditions compared to reactions using stoichiometric reagents and human health.


Last Modified: 11/22/2019
Modified by: Weiping Tang
